title: Lincoln Chafee drops out of presidential race ‘after much thought’
text: By Eric Levenson @ejleven Boston.com Staff | 10.23.15 | 8:46 AM Longshot Democratic presidential candidate Lincoln Chafee bowed out of the 2016 race on Friday, he said in a statement. “As you know I have been campaigning on a platform of Prosperity Through Peace. But after much thought I have decided to end my campaign for president today. I would like to take this opportunity one last time to advocate for a chance be given to peace,” he said. The former Rhode Island governor and senator had little to no support in early polls, and put in a widely-mocked performance at the first Democratic debate last week. Advertisement - Continue Reading Below Chafee is the third Democratic challenger who has stepped out of the race in recent days. Vice President Joe Biden decided not to run on Wednesday, and former Virginia senator Jim Webb said goodbye on Tuesday. Chafee said in his statement that he was worried Republicans would set back women’s rights and is looking forward to a Democratic victory. “Since today is all about women’s leadership it reminds me of one of my favorite Greek plays; Lysistrata, a comedy from about 400 BCE by Aristophanes. In that play, a group of women, fed up with the war mongering of their husbands, agree to withhold their favors until peace returns. And it worked!” OK, Lincoln, sure. Thanks for the memories. Gallery: The quixotic presidential race of Lincoln Chafee Lincoln Chafee, former Rhode Island Republican senator and independent-turned-Democratic governor, dropped out of the 2016 race for president Friday. Eric Thayer / The New York Times According to RealClearPolitics, Chafee was polling at 0.0 percent. Jim Cole / AP Shortly after Chafee announced his presidential campaign, his wife posted on social media asking if anyone had the former governor’s Facebook password, which had gotten lost. Jonathan Ernst / Reuters The son of a U.S. senator, Chafee, 62, graduated from Brown Univeristy and moved to Montana to learn horseshoeing, before returning to the Ocean State to get started in politics. Charlie Neibergall / AP In New Hampshire, where Chafee frequently made campaign stops at small-town political gatherings, his polling average was 0.8 percent. Cheryl Senter / The Boston Globe
